what is the main reason a lot of your songs are so short?

You wrote a lot of your songs before recording them. Are there some you didnt do that for and wrote while recording? I'm crazy/it's raining?

i was experimenting with in-studio writing during the first half of 2011. i ultimately decided that i can do better work when i finalize the writing before the recording takes place. this does not mean finalize all of the instrumental parts, it just means the melody, lyric, chords, and especially the road map need to be set in stone before the recording starts. crazy/raining was written before the recording. but that doesn't mean all the little percussion fills and instrumental things were pre-written, just the melody, lyric, chords, and road map

it's really just to make it work on the staff, because a key signature has to set you up so you have 1 of each letter. otherwise the key of F# would have 2 F's at the same time (F and F#) or the key of Gb (same key actually) would have 2 B's (B and Bb) and it would be a disaster on the staff, you would have to keep flattening and unflattening the B even just to write like a normal Gb major melody. it's really just to make the scale work with all the letters in a row. that's the point of key signatures. it's like 7 people with names A thru G have to represent the scale by holding up sharp/flat signs (or no sign). if you were not allowed to use E#, then the only way to make the key of F# would be to clone Frannie and kill Eddie

What is your percentage of honesty while answering these questions?

the vast majority are 100% honest, but occasionaly i might answer a question from an entirely fictional point of view, and it is usually very easy to tell. for example, the last question i answered fictionally was "i love you, will you run away with me." i answered "sure" because i wanted to express a generally positive sentiment for the idea, but the reality is that i will probably never find out who asked that, and the likelihood that we could 'run away' together would depend on whether or not the destination would be a place where there is a good studio space and/or writing environment, and also whether that person would be the right person to form a mutually beneficial and collaborative relationship. the reason i chose the fictional answer was because i felt it had a stronger value to the reader, and also mirrored the fictional (and carefree) nature of the question itself

So I got access to many professional Big Band charts. I play to them on drums, but I think it would be cool to play to them on my keyboard. I know all the basics of a keyboard, because I'm a percussionist, and I know this will sound stupid, but what's Fm7 or Bb7 mean and how the Fuck do you play them. I believe they're chords, but what's the 7 mean??

play the Ab note just below middle C, and also the Eb right above middle C. then play the F that is 2 and a half octaves below middle C. that is the Fmin7 chord. now for the other chord, keep all the notes the same but for the bass note, play Bb instead of F, and that high Eb move it down to D. that is how you play those 2 chords, in the context you are referring to
